Context:
The School of Hospitality and Tourism Management at the college offers a Tourism and Hospitality Management Program with a "common first year approach." In the first year, students gain knowledge in hotels, event planning, tourism, and food and beverage through practical and theoretical courses.

In the second year, students broaden their understanding of tourism-specific niche sectors, global issues, impacts, and challenges facing the industry with courses in culinary tourism, heritage tourism, sustainable tourism, and international tourism.

As part of the fourth semester, students complete a 14-week industry externship, either nationally or internationally, to gain real-world experience and start building their network of contacts.

Graduates will receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, TICO Travel Counsellor Certification, and first aid (CPR). They also have the option to participate in an exclusive Experiential Study Tour. Students can switch into any of the hospitality and tourism management programs by their second year if their interest changes.

The program prepares students for careers in travel and tour companies, tourism organizations and associations, hotels and resorts, conference and convention centers, private clubs, wellness centers, community centers, cruise ships, airlines, and government agencies.

Qualified graduates may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program at George Brown College as an advanced standing student in September.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Tourism and Hospitality Management Program H130 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. The Hospitality degree program at George Brown College has advanced standing options in September and January. There is also an option to start in the spring bridging semester from May to August.
2. The minimum grade point average required to qualify for this educational path is 2.7.
3. Articulation options can be discussed with a program coordinator.
4. Required courses for the Hospitality degree program are spread across four semesters:
   Semester 1:
   - HOST 1085: Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management
   - HOST 1171: Global Accommodation Industry
   - HOST 1172: Introduction to Wines and Beverages
   - HOST 1070: Introduction to Catering
   - COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts
   - MATH 1250: Introduction to Management Numeracy with Excel Applications
   - HOST 1068: Smart Serve (online certificate)
   - HOSF 1145: Sanitation (online certificate)
   - HOSF 1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)

   Semester 2:
   - HOST 1174: Remarkable Restaurant Service – An Introduction to the Industry
   - HOST 1043: Special Events Planning and Delivery
   - HOST 1173: Hospitality Marketing and Social Media
   - HOST 1160: Career Preparation
   - HOST 1175: Global Tourism Geography*
   - HRM 1015: Human Resources Management*
   - LAW 1017: Introduction to Hospitality Law*
   - ACCT 1048: Hospitality Accounting*
   - GSCI 1035: Science of Sustainability

   Semester 3:
   - ACCT 2017: Managerial Accounting
   - HOST 1049: Sustainable Tourism
   - HOST 2085: International Tourism Cultures and Behaviour
   - HOST 2093: Leading Change in Digital Tourism
   - HOST 1156: Culinary Tourism*
   - HOST 1091: Heritage Tourism*
   - GNED: General Education Elective

   Semester 4:
   - HOST 2053: Tourism Management Capstone (online)
   - HOST 2130: Industry Externship
   - GNED: General Education Elective
5. Some courses are seven-week courses marked with an asterisk (*).
6. Students may be required to take COMM 1000: Introduction to College Communication based on the results of their placement test.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Tourism and Hospitality Management Program H130 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Provide professional guest services to enhance customer satisfaction
- Create marketing plans informed by market research and sales strategies
- Contribute to effective management in hospitality, tourism and leisure settings
- Evaluate and apply financial management and accounting practices
- Comply with organizational and workplace systems, processes, policies, standards, legal obligations and regulations
- Apply principles of teamwork and constructive relationship management
- Integrate hospitality skills and knowledge to promote ongoing personal and professional development
- Design and deliver inclusive tourism and hospitality programs, products and services that comply with legislation and ethical guidelines
- Analyze and implement sustainability practices in the tourism and hospitality industry

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,548.00 (for first two semesters starting Fall 2022)
- International Tuition: $18,547.00 (for first two semesters starting Fall 2023)
- Additional Costs: $575 (textbooks and manuals; subject to change)
- Included in material fees is a uniform (black pants, grey Oxford shirt and a bib apron)

Context:
The text provides information about fees, financial assistance, admission requirements, course exemptions, international students, health policy, and contact details for domestic and financial inquiries at George Brown College. Here are some key factual points extracted from the text:

1. Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding.
2. Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, Grade 12 English (C or U), selective admission for Hospitality Services (Pre-Hospitality) applicants, mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to achieve English credit.
3. Course Exemptions: College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions; consult the Transfer Guide for more information.
4. International Students: Visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements, apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
5. Health Policy: Allergens such as nuts, dairy, and shellfish are used in practical labs, sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.
6. Contact Information for Inquiries: Domestic students should contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page. For financial/fees inquiries, please contact Financial/Fees at [email address unavailable].
